titleStmt.title: The English villain: or The grand thief. Being a full relation of the desperate life, and deserved death of that most notable thief, and notorious robber, Richard Hanam: who for his arch villanies, and notorious robberies committed both in England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, Denmark, Sweden, yea, Rome it self; far exceeds that arch villain the Spanish Gusman, and the late famous robber of England Captain Iames Hind; yea, and all the notorious thieves that ever yet were heard of: the like to whom hath not been known. With the manner of the execution, and his speech at his last farewell to the world. Licensed and entred according to Order.

titleStmt.title: The English villain: or The grand thief. Being a full relation of the desperate life, and deserved death of that most notable thief, and notorious robber, Richard Hanam: who for his arch villanies, and notorious robberies committed both in England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, Denmark, Sweden, yea, Rome it self; far exceeds that arch villain the Spanish Gusman, and the late famous robber of England Captain Iames Hind; yea, and all the notorious thieves that ever yet were heard of: the like to whom hath not been known. With the manner of the execution, and his speech at his last farewell to the world. Licensed and entred according to Order.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Engli≈øh Villain: Of the GRAND THIEF.

A full Relation of the de≈øperate Life, and de ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ved Death of that mo≈øt notable Thief, and notorious Robber, Richard Hanam: Who for his arch Villanies, and notorious Robberies committed both in England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, Denmark, Sweden, yea, Rome it ≈øelf; far exceeds that arch Villain the Spani≈øh Gu≈øman, and the late famous Robber of England Captain Iames Hind; yea, and all the notorious Thieves that ever yet were heard of: the like to whom hath not been known.
With the manner of the Execution, and his Speech at his la≈øt farewell to the World.

p.hi: Licen≈øed and Entred according to Order.

div.p: London, Printed for Iohn Andrews, at the white Lion in the Old-Baily.

div.head: The Engli≈øh Villain.
div.p: CAptain Hanam the ≈øubject of this di≈øcou≈øe, was by birth an Engli≈øhman, and a mo≈øt proper compleat man for per≈øon; but for thieving and picking of locks and bolts, and other ≈øuch like exploits, he was ≈øo expert, that ≈øcarce ever the like was heard of. For being ≈øeveral times apprehended both for murthers and robberies, he always e≈øcaped by breaking out of pri≈øon; in≈øomuch that he him≈øelf boa≈øted, that he had broken forth almo≈øt all the pri≈øons in Holland, when he had bin ≈øeveral times committed: the like to whom hath not been heard of before, as ≈øhall be made appear in this following di≈øcour≈øe.
How Hanam pa≈ø≈øed beyond ≈øea; and how he fir≈øt robbed the King of Denmark, and after pa≈ø≈øed into Sweden.

HAnam having now for divers yeares exerci≈øed him≈øelf in his accur≈øed and
wicked Art of Thieving, whereby many were utterly undone by him; and being guilty of very many horrid and bloody murthers by him committed; for to ≈øecure him≈øelf from the claws of the Hang-man, he pa≈ø≈øed over into Denmark, where among ≈øeveral other exploits and robberies by him committed, he having intelligence where the Kings Trea≈øure lay, by the help of his Picklocks, and other in≈øtruments, in which wicked, but cunning Art he exelled all others, by which he ≈øoon got him≈øelf ma≈øter of a very rich Trea≈øury of the Kings, out of which having ≈øufficiently furni≈øhed him≈øelf, he departed thence into Swedeland.
How Hanam Robbed the Queen of Swedes, of all her rich Iewels, with other great ≈øums of money, to the value of five thou≈øand pound.

HAnam having committed the fore≈øaid robbery on the King of Denmark
for fear of being apprehended for the ≈øame, departs into Swedeland, where comming to the Court he made him≈øelf familiar under the pretence of an Engli≈øh Gentleman, and being very conver≈øant about the Queen, he ≈øoon heard out where her Trea≈øure lay, for that was the thing he aimed at, and he had not been long acquainted thereof, but he attempts the gaining of it, which by the help of his Picklocks he ≈øoon made him≈øelf ma≈øter of all, and got a rich booty, being all for the mo≈øt part very rich and co≈øtly Jewels, which, with other great ≈øums of money, amounted to five thou≈øand pound: After this, Hanam being apprehended confe≈øt the bu≈øine≈øs, and was for this bold attempt committed clo≈øe Pri≈øoner to the common Goal, or main Pri≈øoner, there to remain untill the times of A≈ø≈øizes, that ≈øo hee might receive the reward that was due unto him.
How Hanam broke out of pri≈øon, and after got into France, and there robbed the King of France of ≈øeveral great ≈øums of money.

HAnam being now a pri≈øoner, and the time of Se≈ø≈øions, or Goal- „Äà‚óä„Äâ drawing near in which he knew'h ≈øhould be brought to Execution for his roguery, and not being willing as yet to be hinged; he made a de≈øperate attempt, and ‚Ä¢ o broke the pri≈øon, notwith≈øtanding it was made ≈øure with ≈øeveral ≈øtrong bolts and bars of Iron, which as was conceived, all the „Äà‚óä„Äâ and art of man could not undoe: All which Hanam undid by his in≈øtruments, and ≈øo e≈øcaped thence into France. Where Gentleman like he continued a while about the Court, waiting for ≈øome opportunity: which having gotten, he ≈øoon made u≈øe of, and ≈øo robbed the French King of ≈øeveral great ≈øums of money.

How Hanam after this, departed out of France into the Low-Countreys, and how he committed ≈øeveral Robberies there: Among
others, how he robbed the King of Scots at the Hague in Holland.

HAnam having by his ≈øubtilties got him≈øelf out of pri≈øon, and after robbed the King of France, dur≈øt not (being an Engli≈øh man) continue any longer within the French Kings dominions; whereupon he departed thence into Holland, where in a very ≈øhort time he committed ≈øeveral murthers and robberies up and down the Low-Countreys. Afterwards comming to the Hague, where the King of Scots then lay, Hanam likewi≈øe robbed him of that ≈ømall portion of ≈øtock which he had for his nece≈ø≈øary reliefe and ≈øu≈øtenance. After which, committing ≈øeveral great robberies upon divers per≈øons of quality, he was at la≈øt taken, and committed to pri≈øon: where he had not long been, but he (as formerly he had done) broke out of pri≈øon, and ≈øo e≈øcaped.
How Hanam came into England again: and how he made an attempt to have robbed his Highne≈øs Trea≈øury of the Exchequer.

HAnam being now at liberty again; and having as he thought quite ≈ølipt his neck out of the halter, he began to grow very bold and in≈øolent, and to glory in his vilene≈ø≈øe, ≈øuppo≈øing him≈øelf able to get forth of any Pri≈øon what≈øoever, be returned again into England, and ≈øo came to London, where not contenting him≈øelf with other robberies, his thoughts were to have robbed his Highne≈øs Trea≈øury in the Exchequer; and for that purpo≈øe, having taken a view thereof, he began this „Äà‚óä„Äâ in the beginning of the night; but „Äà‚óä„Äâ being taken of his fore≈øaid viewing of the place, and ≈øome other information of his de≈øign aimed at, Musquetiers were ≈øet to watch his comming, Hanam not mi≈øtru≈øting any di≈øcovery of his de≈øign, proceeded in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, opening five or ≈øix double locked doors, through the help of his Picklocks and other in≈øtruments for that purpo≈øe, the ≈øouldiers all this while watching him, ‚Ä¢ uffered him to go on, till at la≈øt being got to the door of the Chamber where the mony ≈øay, which being very
≈øtrong, and al≈øo barr'd on the in≈øide with three ≈øeveral ≈øtrong Bars of Iron, they „Äà‚óä„Äâ he could not ea≈øily get open; but notwith≈øtanding, he ≈øoon got loo≈øe all tho≈øe and entred the room, but hearing the Souldiers begin to bu≈øtle up ≈øtairs after „Äà‚óä„Äâ , he could not take his opportunity but got through a private pa≈ø≈øage, and ≈øo e≈øcaped.
How Heynam was after taken, and ≈øo brought to Newgate.

HAnam being di≈øappointed of the la≈øt intended de≈øign, and by the ble≈ø≈øing of God hindred by the Souldiers from robbing the Common wealth of five or ≈øix thou≈øand pound, which lay ready in bags in the Exchequer Chamber, great ≈øearch was now made for him in all places ≈øu≈øpected; and in a ≈ømall time after he was by the indu≈øtry of the Souldiers di≈øcovered and apprehended, and ≈øo brought before the Judges at We≈øtmin≈øter, where being examined, he openly confe≈ø≈øed that he had committed ≈øeverall Robberies, and
gloried, that he could ea≈øily open any door or lock what≈øoever; and pretended, that if the Judges would goe along with him them≈øelves over the water, he would ≈øhew them where his in≈øtruments were made. But the Honourable Judges ≈øu≈øpecting ≈øome wicked De≈øigne upon their per≈øons, committed him to the Gatehou≈øe, from whence he was ≈øhortly after removed to Newgate, there to be kept until the time of Se≈ø≈øions.

How Hanam being pri≈øoner in Newgate, was brought down to the Se≈ø≈øions-Hou≈øe in the Old Baily, and tried for his life before the Right Honourable the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Recorder of the City of London: where after a ≈øhort examination, his facts being al≈øo notoriou≈øly known, he was condemned to ≈øuffer death at Tyburn.

HAnam being now a pri≈øoner in the pri≈øon of Newgate, in ≈øhort time after his comming thither, the General Se≈ø≈øions and A≈ø≈øizes began in the Old-Bayly: Where the Right Honourable the Lord
Mayor, and the re≈øt of the Ju≈øtices of the Bench being ≈øet; Hanam was brought before them; and being examined by the Honourable Bench, was pre≈øently found Guilty, and convicted of ≈øeveral horrid and de≈øperate bloudy murthers, and notorious robberies, and was by the Jury found guilty of the ≈øame. Whereupon the Right Honorable the Recorder then pre≈øent, immediately pa≈ø≈øed ≈øentence of death again≈øt him, That he ≈øhould ≈øuffer Death at the place of Execution, by being hanged by the neck till he died. After which, he was conveyed back to Newgate again, there to remain till the day of Execution.
How Hanam after he was condemned to die, made his e≈øcape out of Newgate: and how little Grimes, the under Clerk, was hanged for con≈øenting to his e≈øcape.

HAnam being now condemned to die, and the day of Execution drawing nigh, he re≈øolved to make one de≈øperate attempt for to make an e≈øcape; quickly effected, to the wonder of all that beheld
the ≈øame, the like having never been ≈øeen or done before, and this his de≈øign be mane on Grimes formerly a Pri≈øoner in the ≈øame place, and one who had been condemned for having two Wives; but was afterward Reprieved for that offence and at that time executed the place of an under Clerk in the ≈øaid Pri≈øon of Newgate; now this Grimes lying in the room with Hanom, was made Privy to his e≈øcape, which he willingly contented to, and ≈øo ≈øuffered him by his women cunning to take off his Irons, with which he was fettered; which as the ≈øaid Grimes confe≈ø≈øed before the Honourable Bench, he did u≈øe to do with ea≈øe every night, and ≈øo put them on in the morning: Now Hanam having taken off his Iron chains, pre≈øently breaks open three or four great dores, and breaks in ≈øunder all the great Chains and Iron Bars, and ≈øo e≈øcaped clear away, leaving little Grimes to an≈øwer for his Treachery, who afterwards, contrary to his own expectation, was condemned to die for the ≈øame, and accordingly ≈øuffered death at Tyburn for the ≈øaid fact.
How Hanam was pur≈øued after, and retaken again, and how he was brought to London, and within ≈øight of Newgate, and yet made his e≈øcape again.

HAnam being now at liberty by breaking of Pri≈øon, great ≈øearch and inquiry was made after him and within a while after was taken in the Country and ≈øo ≈øent up to London, and ≈øo conveyed towards Newgate; but comming within the fight of Newgate, he made a de≈øperate attempt, and got from them, and ≈øo e≈øcaped again.
How Hanam after his ≈øecond e≈øcape went to Rome, and there committed ≈øeveral robberies more, e≈øpecially, he robbed the late Queen of Sweden in her Nunnery.

HAnam being now gotten at liberty once more, to prevent his being taken
again, got over again beyond ≈øea, and ≈øo ≈øteered his cour≈øe towards Rome, where being arrived, he began to exerci≈øe his old accu≈øtomed trade of thieving and robbery again. And having robbed ≈øeveral rich per≈øons, he re≈øolved once more to make an attempt upon the late Queen of Sweden again: Which he effected in the Nunnery where ≈øhe frequented, and to which ≈øhe had betaken her ≈øelfe, and where ≈øhee had laid up her trea≈øure; which Hanam having taken notice of, pre≈øently made him≈øelf ma≈øter thereof, And having continued in this trade a while, he returned again towards England.

How Hanam after his return to England was taken near Swithins Lane, London, on the 14, of Iune, and ≈øo brought to Newgate the next morning, and afterwards executed for all his former villanies, on the 17 of Iune, 1656.

HAnam having imployed him≈øelfe a while in his arch-trade of thieving at Rome, he returned again towards England,
and ≈øo came to London; where being in company near Swithins Lane, London, a drinking, he endeavoured to make him≈øelf ma≈øter of a ≈øum of money, which hee had ≈øome notice of, that was in the hou≈øe, which they thought to have po≈ø≈øe≈øt them≈øelves of while they ≈øtaid there drinking: But notice being given thereof, endeavors were u≈øed for to apprehend them. And the thieves (of which Hanam was one) being ≈øhut up into a room, got away over the hou≈øes: but returning again, he was taken, having de≈øperately wounded two or three men fir≈øt, and ≈øo kept in ≈øafe cu≈øtody till the morning. Which being come, it being the Lords Day, he was very ≈øtrongly guarded to Newgate; and the Keepers to prevent his further e≈øcape, bound him hands and feet with ≈øtrong chains and fetters of Iron, where multitudes daily flocked to ≈øee him, expecting his Execution: which to give the Gallowes and Hang-man their due, was performed in Smithfield the 17. day of this pre≈øent moneth; where as he lived wickedly, he al≈øo died wilfully and de≈øperately,
and ≈øo bid farewel to the World.

Thus have you heard a brief, but true account of the rude life, and notable Villanies committed by this wretched and unparalell'd Villain, with his de≈øperate but de≈øerved ≈øhamefull Death; the like to whom hath not been, nor I hope never will be again.
div.l: And for his Thefts and Villanies,
at the Gallows had his due.
